message.content: We refer to WikiDoc articles on medicine for help. The patient has third-degree burns involving approximately 11% of TBSA, indicating that immediate surgical intervention is necessary to prevent complications such as infection and fluid loss. Early excision and split-thickness skin grafting are recommended for such cases. Delayed excision and skin grafting is not recommended for extensive third-degree burns as it increases the risk of infection and delays wound healing. Topical antibiotic application of mafenide acetate can be used to prevent infection but is not the most appropriate next step in management. Fluid resuscitation with Ringer’s lactate solution per the Parkland formula is necessary for burns involving more than 15-20% TBSA, and therefore not the most appropriate for this patient.
